head.title: Miso's Ready To Become A Player

hedline.hl1: Miso's Ready To Become A Player

abstract.p: Mark Bittman describes making pork cutlet with miso sauce; recipe (S)

block.p: NOT long ago, miso was found almost exclusively in Japanese markets and health food stores. It was used in not much more than soup.
Now, you can buy it in many supermarkets, and you should definitely try it in many more dishes.
NOT long ago, miso was found almost exclusively in Japanese markets and health food stores. It was used in not much more than soup.
Now, you can buy it in many supermarkets, and you should definitely try it in many more dishes.

Miso is a paste produced from fermented soybeans; it has an intense flavor -- sweeter, saltier and more complex than soy sauce. But it is also a superb thickener: whisk it into a small amount of liquid and it creates a rich, creamy consistency.
When you add it with a little wine to the juices in a saute pan after searing a pork chop, it becomes a great sauce with almost no work.
You brown the pork on both sides, reduce the red wine and stir in the miso until the sauce is smooth.
If you want to add a garnish, you can use any herb, but I like shiso, a leaf that is sometimes called Japanese basil and has a flavor something like a cross between basil and mint.
The only caution in cooking with miso is that it must be handled gently; high heat practically destroys its flavor.
For the pork, I prefer a bone-in chop, from the rib end of the loin if possible. It's a little bit fattier than other chops, which is a benefit rather than a detriment, since modern pork is so lean.
Boneless steaks from the loin or tenderloin can be substituted, as can many cuts of beef, like rib-eye, strip or skirt steaks. Just remember to reduce the cooking time slightly.
A red wine with some body works well here, one from the south of France or a California zinfandel or cabernet sauvignon. It doesn't have to be expensive, but it should be good enough to drink.
Red miso, which is actually brown, is best for this dish, not least because it is the easiest to find. It also adds terrific color to the sauce.
PORK CUTLET WITH MISO SAUCE Time: 20 minutes
4 1-inch-thick bone-in pork chops, each about 6 ounces Salt and freshly cracked black pepper 1 cup sturdy red wine, like Cotes du Rhone or cabernet sauvignon 2 tablespoons red miso
1/4 cup roughly chopped shiso, basil or parsley, optional.

1. Heat a heavy skillet over medium-high heat 2 to 3 minutes, then add the chops. Sprinkle them with a little salt and a lot of pepper. Brown them on one side 4 to 5 minutes. Turn and brown the other side until chop is firm and nearly cooked through, 3 or 4 minutes. Remove to a warm plate, and turn the heat to medium.

2. Add wine and cook, stirring occasionally with a wooden spoon to loosen any bits of meat that have stuck to the pan, until the wine reduces by about half. Turn heat to low, and add miso; stir briskly until smooth (a wire whisk will help).
3. Taste the sauce, and if necessary, add more pepper and salt. Spoon sauce over the chops, garnish with herbs if you like, and serve. Yield: 4 servings.
